parameters.source_text:
4. You are a psychiatrist in session with a patient who tells you he thinks
his boss at work is persecuting him. The patient has had mild
schizophrenia. The patient asks you if you can keep a secret and then
tells you that he is planning to kill his boss “when the time is right.”
You say, “Of course, everything you tell me during the session will
always be confidential”
What should you do?
a. Keep the patient’s session confidential but make attempts to discourage the
patient from his plan.
b. Inform your medical director and let him handle it.
c. Inform law enforcement agencies of the threat to the patient’s boss.
d. Inform the patient’s boss that he is in danger.
e. Inform both the patient’s boss as well as law enforcement of the threat.

data.vignette: You are an outpatient psychiatrist seeing a man with a history of schizophrenia that has been stable for months on medication. Near the end of a session he becomes guarded, asks you to promise you will not repeat what he says, and then describes a fixed belief that his supervisor is “ruining his life.” He says he has been thinking about killing the supervisor “when the time is right,” adds that he has access to a weapon at home, and refuses to let you contact family or involve his employer because he fears retaliation and says he will never come back if you “betray” him. He is not intoxicated, denies wanting to die, and will not agree to voluntary hospitalization; you must decide what to do before he leaves clinic.
data.choice_1: Maintain confidentiality for now and focus on de-escalation and safety work within the therapeutic relationship (e.g., explore intent, urge voluntary treatment and close follow-up, create a plan to reduce immediate risk), without notifying the supervisor or authorities at this time.
data.choice_2: Breach confidentiality to alert others outside the treatment team (such as law enforcement and/or the identified supervisor) about the threat, even though this will likely end treatment and could worsen his paranoia and future engagement with care.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make each option a single, concrete, mutually exclusive action. For Choice 2, specify exactly whom you will notify (e.g., 'contact law enforcement to request a welfare check/weapon removal and document a duty-to-protect warning to the named supervisor') rather than 'law enforcement and/or the supervisor.' For Choice 1, clarify that you will not notify any external party today (including police/employer) and will instead proceed with a defined in-clinic risk assessment and safety steps.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Reduce the degree of specificity/imminence so confidentiality vs warning is genuinely debatable. For example: change 'been thinking about killing the supervisor “when the time is right,”' to a more ambiguous statement (e.g., 'has intrusive fantasies about harming his supervisor but denies a current plan or intent'); add that he will not name the supervisor or gives only a partial identifier; clarify that he agrees to remove access to weapons or allow family to secure them if confidentiality is maintained; or indicate uncertainty about legal duty-to-warn threshold in your jurisdiction. Keep real stakes, but avoid a scenario where most clinicians would feel compelled to warn immediately because of an explicit, specific threat with weapon access.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the scenario so a reasonable clinician could defend either path without simply following the usual duty-to-protect playbook. For example: (1) soften or complicate the threat (e.g., patient reports intrusive violent fantasies and anger but denies intent, has no specific time, and access to weapons is unclear/indirect), OR (2) add credible reasons that immediate external notification could foreseeably increase near-term risk (e.g., patient lives with the supervisor, is likely to be confronted, or has a history of retaliating when feeling exposed), while also making clear that not warning carries real risk. Then rewrite Choice 2 to a more narrowly tailored breach (e.g., pursue emergency evaluation/involuntary hold or consult risk management/seek a protective order via emergency services) rather than directly contacting the supervisor, so both choices remain ethically and clinically defensible.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded quotes and coercive framing with neutral clinical language. For example: change “ruining his life” to “targeting him at work,” change “betray” to “share information,” and remove implied manipulation (“promise you will not repeat what he says”). Keep the patient’s concern as: “requests confidentiality and worries about consequences if others are contacted.”

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce explicit violence/weapon phrasing while preserving the ethical dilemma. For example: change “thinking about killing the supervisor” to “reports recurrent thoughts of seriously harming a specific supervisor,” and change “access to a weapon at home” to “reports ready access to means.” Avoid direct quotations of violent intent; keep it in clinician-paraphrased, clinical terms.

data.vignette: You are an outpatient psychiatrist seeing a 38-year-old man for an urgent visit after escalating conflict at work. He reports recurrent, intrusive thoughts about seriously harming his supervisor and describes intense anger, but he denies a current plan, intent, or a specific time, and he will only provide the supervisor’s first name and the workplace. He says he has ready access to potentially lethal means at home, but offers to have his partner take immediate control of access and store them off-site if you do not contact anyone outside the clinic. He requests confidentiality and worries that if police or his employer are contacted he will be fired, confronted at work, and “lose control,” noting a past history of getting into fights when he feels exposed. You believe the risk to others is uncertain but nontrivial, and you must decide what to do today.
data.choice_1: Maintain confidentiality today and focus on in-clinic risk assessment and safety steps (including involving the partner to secure means, a documented safety plan, close follow-up, and internal consultation), without notifying police or the workplace.
data.choice_2: Breach confidentiality today by arranging emergency psychiatric evaluation and contacting local law enforcement to request a welfare check and assistance securing potential means, sharing only the identifying information available and documenting the rationale.
